bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, January 9, 1948

div1.p: Hench wants to know if McCoy is still alive. He discusses the biography by Hagedorn which credits Wood with the suggestion that led Sternberg to form the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, January 9, 1948
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
January 9, 1948
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
Brigadier General J. R. Kean
2804 N Street Northwest
Georgetown, Washington, D. C.
Dear General Kean:

item.p:
1. Is Major General Frank R. McCoy still living presumably in
Atlanta, Georgia? I am going to Atlanta in two weeks to give three talks
at a Post-Graduate Medical Assembly. If General McCoy is living I'd like
to see him as Hagedorn in his Biography of Leonard Wood (Harpers 1931) Volume
1, page 332 states “Twice indeed, the investigation (Reed's) had nearly been
stopped by orders from the Surgeon General, who needed his doctors and felt
that too much time had already been wasted, but each time Wood had intervened
and saved the commission” (Ref. 23, McCoy from the S. G., 1929).

I've never seen such messages or orders and never heard of them
before. What think you?

2. On page 281, Hagedorn credits Wood with the suggestion which
led Sternberg to form the Y. F. Commission. Hagedorn says “Wood, thoroughly
baffled, appointed Gorgas, Chief Sanitory Officer of Havana and gave him ample
funds; urged Sternberg, the Surgeon General of the Army, to appoint a special
scientific commission to study the problem of the origin of yellow fever;
(Ref. 15, Wood to E. F. Wood, Dec. 27, 1919), kept the streets spotless,
etc.” The E. F. Wood reference is given on page 430 as a book.

I'm trying to find the book. "Eric Fisher Wood: Leonard Wood,
Conservator of Americanism. (Year and publisher not given).

div1.p:
This does not entirely suprise me because the correspondence
between Howard (L. O.) and Reed in the spring of 1900 shows clearly that
Reed at least had no idea a Y. F. Commission was to be formed and in one
letter shortly before the Y. F. board was formed Reed wrote Howard regarding
quite different plans which Sternberg seemed to have for him (Reed). Even
though Sternberg may have thought independently about forming another Y. F.
board (but maybe he didn't, as at least two had already failed) it certainly
appears that the decision of Sternberg to appoint the board was a sudden one
of which Reed was unaware. Perhaps it was a strong suggestion from Wood
(in Cuba, worried about Y. F.) which deceided Sternberg rather suddenly to
appoint the board and change Reed's plans of which he'd written Howard.

Please used the enclosed envelope for reply. If General McCoy
still lives I want to write him ahead of time.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:pam
P. S. I have accepted the invitations I got to speak in England in October
1948, so I will be going to Europe this fall.
